title: Network Advice for A School E-Sports Club
body: Our high school has a club for e-sports and some other games students want to play. Mainly we play Smash 4, Overwatch and of course League. So far during meetings club members have been able to play Overwatch and I believe also Smite on the school network without a ton of lag issues and disconnects. League is another story. On the same network and switch as the people using Overwatch on other computers, League is entirely unplayable and disconnects constantly. We have determined that the network bandwidth available is not an issue, and neither are the PC's, as the game runs smoothly. However, I believe our school may be blocking some of League's needed outgoing network ports even though the game was supposedly approved by the school. What network ports does the League client and game each separately use? Client and chat work fine, but the games do not. In addition, I believe since our school has many computers yet uses the same external IP when connecting to Riot's servers this may also be causing an issue in network performance. Any ideas on why the game performance is bad on a school network? Anyone have more experience than I do on how generally school networks are set up by the network administrator?

replies.body:
It kind of sounds like your schools network might have certain ports blocked which would cause those issues. Have your school's IT admin check to make sure these ports are open for League's servers...

Ports needed for servers:
5000 - 5500 UDP (League of Legends Game Client)
8393 - 8400 TCP (Patcher and Maestro)
2099 TCP (PVP.Net)
5223 TCP (PVP.Net)
5222 TCP (PVP.Net)
80 TCP (HTTP Connections)
443 TCP (HTTPS Connections)
8088 UDP and TCP (Spectator Mode)

If that doesn't help, you might need to have that admin reach out via a school e-mail to get whitelisted.

Ok I will check with the school IT admin and club leader on which port exceptions we need to make. Is there anything else about how leagues servers treat the incoming requests network that would help us in setting up the network security correctly?
